posts.author: Partagas
posts.title: AWFL New Yorkers: Women are unsafe in this city. They are being set on fire in the subway.            Also AWFL New Yorkers: I voted for the guy who plans to defund the Police and eliminate bail.

posts.raw_content:
In this hypothetical scenario, Curtis Sliwa, the Republican nominee and founder of the Guardian Angels, wins the 2025 New York City mayoral election on November 4, 2025, capitalizing on a deeply divided electorate, voter dissatisfaction with incumbent Eric Adams, a splintered Democratic vote, and heightened concerns over crime, taxes, and illegal immigration. The Democratic nominee, Zohran Mamdani, faces challenges from his progressive platform, which alienates moderate and conservative voters, while former Governor Andrew Cuomo runs as an independent, splitting the Democratic vote. Adams, also running as an independent, draws significant support from Black voters but struggles with low approval ratings. Sliwa’s victory hinges on consolidating Republican and moderate voters, leveraging his public safety message, and benefiting from a low-turnout election where his base shows up reliably.
Key Factors and Data Analysis
Voter Demographics and Turnout
New York City’s Electoral Landscape: NYC has approximately 5.5 million registered voters, with Democrats outnumbering Republicans 7 to 1 (roughly 3.5 million Democrats, 500,000 Republicans, and 1.5 million independents or other affiliations). In the 2021 mayoral election, turnout was low, with only 1.1 million voters casting ballots in the general election. Assuming a similar turnout in 2025 (around 20-25% of registered voters), approximately 1.1-1.4 million votes will be cast.

Sliwa’s Base: Sliwa’s core support comes from Republicans (500,000), conservative-leaning independents, and moderates concerned about crime and taxes. In 2021, Sliwa garnered 27% of the vote (approximately 300,000 votes) against Adams. Polls suggest he could maintain or slightly increase this share, targeting 30-35% (330,000-490,000 votes) in a multi-candidate race. His appeal is strongest among older voters (over 50), who prioritize crime and public safety (26% of voters cite this as their top issue).

Turnout Advantage: Republicans and older voters historically turn out more reliably in low-turnout elections. With Democrats split between Mamdani, Cuomo, and Adams, Sliwa’s base could represent a disproportionate share of the electorate. Posts on X suggest GOP enthusiasm, with calls to “show up strong” for Sliwa.

Splitting the Democratic Vote
Zohran Mamdani (Democratic Nominee): Mamdani, a 33-year-old progressive and Democratic Socialist, wins the Democratic primary with 52% in a ranked-choice voting simulation, defeating Cuomo. His platform—free buses, rent freezes, and city-owned grocery stores—resonates with younger voters (18-34, who prioritize housing at 45%) but alienates moderates and older voters due to his perceived radicalism and controversial stances, such as refusing to affirm Israel’s right to exist. Polls show Mamdani at 35% in a general election matchup, but his support drops among Black voters (30% compared to Cuomo’s 54%) and moderates.

Andrew Cuomo (Independent): After losing the primary, Cuomo runs on independent ballot lines (“New York City is in Crisis” and “Fight and Deliver”). Polls indicate he could capture 10-15% of the vote (110,000-210,000 votes), drawing from moderate Democrats, Black voters (54% backed him in polls), and Jewish voters. His campaign focuses on crime and affordability, siphoning votes from Mamdani among voters wary of progressive policies.

Eric Adams (Independent): Adams, running on “EndAntiSemitism” and “Safe&Affordable” ballot lines, leverages his tough-on-crime record and appeal among Black voters. Polls show him at 10-19% (110,000-266,000 votes), with strong support among Black voters (29% in a Mamdani-led race). His 27% approval rating and 69% unfavorable rating limit his broader appeal, but he retains loyalty in Black communities, particularly in Brooklyn and Queens.

Impact: The three-way split among Mamdani, Cuomo, and Adams fragments the Democratic vote (historically 70-80% in NYC general elections). If Mamdani secures 35% (385,000-490,000 votes), Cuomo 15% (165,000-210,000 votes), and Adams 15% (165,000-210,000 votes), their combined 65% leaves room for Sliwa to win with a plurality of 30-35%.

Key Issues Driving Sliwa’s Campaign
Crime and Public Safety: Crime is the top concern for 26% of voters, particularly older voters, and Sliwa’s platform—restoring NYPD budget cuts, hiring 7,000 officers, and deploying 500 undercover cops in subways—resonates strongly. Adams’ tough-on-crime policies (e.g., reintroducing plainclothes officers) have been criticized, and his 28% approval rating reflects dissatisfaction. Mamdani’s progressive stance on policing (e.g., skepticism of over-policing) is seen as out of touch by 61% of voters who support involuntary removal of homeless individuals from streets and subways.

Illegal Immigration: Sliwa capitalizes on voter frustration with the migrant crisis, a top concern for 7% of voters. His anti-immigration protests (e.g., August 2023 outside Gracie Mansion) and opposition to new migrant shelters align with 30% of voters who view mass deportations positively. Adams’ handling of the migrant crisis has drawn criticism, and Mamdani’s support for strengthening sanctuary city laws alienates conservative and moderate voters.

High Taxes and Affordability: Housing (30%) and the economy/taxes (22%) are top voter concerns. Sliwa’s proposal to fund police by taxing institutions like MSG, NYU, and Columbia appeals to voters frustrated with high taxes. Mamdani’s plans for free buses and universal childcare are seen as tax hikes by moderates, while Cuomo’s tenure as governor is associated with fiscal mismanagement. Posts on X highlight Sliwa as a candidate for “everyday New Yorkers” focused on quality-of-life issues.

Sliwa’s Campaign Strategy
Messaging: Sliwa positions himself as an outsider fighting a corrupt political class, blaming Adams and Cuomo for NYC’s “crime, exodus, and collapse in quality of life.” His focus on public safety, quality-of-life issues (e.g., fare evasion, garbage), and animal welfare (a personal passion) broadens his appeal. He avoids Trump’s endorsement, distancing himself from national GOP politics and calling Adams “the Trump candidate.”

Coalition Building: Sliwa targets Republicans, moderate independents, and disaffected Democrats, particularly in outer boroughs (Staten Island, Queens, and parts of Brooklyn). He secures endorsements from all five NYC Republican county parties and appeals to Jewish voters (concerned about antisemitism) and centrists. His 2021 vote share (27%) and Trump’s 30% in NYC in 2024 suggest a ceiling of 30-35% in a two-way race, but a four-way race lowers the threshold for victory.

Media and Visibility: Sliwa leverages his WABC radio platform and Guardian Angels fame to maintain high name recognition. His red beret and history of bravery (e.g., rescuing a family from a burning building at 15) resonate with voters seeking a non-traditional candidate. Viral campaign moments, like calling out Cuomo’s “cowardice” on a debate stage, energize his base.

Hypothetical Vote Distribution
Total Votes: 1.2 million (assuming 22% turnout).

Sliwa: 35% (420,000 votes) – Captures nearly all Republicans, 50% of independents, and 10% of moderate Democrats, driven by crime and tax concerns.

Mamdani: 30% (360,000 votes) – Wins young progressives and most Democrats but loses moderates and Black voters to Cuomo and Adams.

Cuomo: 15% (180,000 votes) – Draws moderate Democrats, Black voters, and Jewish voters but struggles with progressives and low favorability (47% unfavorable).

Adams: 15% (180,000 votes) – Retains Black voter loyalty (29% support) but is hampered by 69% unfavorable ratings.

Jim Walden (Independent): 5% (60,000 votes) – Gains some anti-establishment voters but lacks Sliwa’s name recognition.

Outcome: Sliwa wins with a plurality, as Mamdani, Cuomo, and Adams split the Democratic-leaning vote (60% combined). The Working Families Party’s potential nomination of a progressive (e.g., Brad Lander) could further dilute Mamdani’s share, but for simplicity, this scenario assumes a four-way race.

Critical Path to Victory
Outer Borough Strength: Sliwa dominates in Staten Island (net negative approval for Adams at -32) and parts of Queens, where crime concerns are acute. He also gains traction in Brooklyn, where Adams’ approval is lowest (-53).

Low Turnout: A turnout of 1.2 million favors Sliwa, as his older, Republican-leaning base is more likely to vote than younger progressives supporting Mamdani.

Debate Performance: Sliwa’s confrontational style, honed on radio and in protests, shines in debates. Calling out Cuomo’s scandals and Mamdani’s “extreme” policies (e.g., “globalize the intifada”) sways undecided voters.

Anti-Establishment Sentiment: With Adams and Cuomo tainted by scandals (Adams’ corruption charges, Cuomo’s harassment allegations), Sliwa’s outsider status and Guardian Angels legacy appeal to voters seeking change.

Mamdani’s Vulnerabilities: Mamdani’s progressive policies (e.g., raising corporate taxes) and controversial stances on Israel lose him moderate Jewish and centrist voters, who shift to Sliwa or Cuomo.

Counterarguments and Risks
Democratic Dominance: NYC’s 7:1 Democratic advantage makes a Republican victory unlikely. Even in a split race, Mamdani could consolidate enough Democratic voters to win, especially if younger voters turn out in higher numbers.

Cuomo’s Independent Run: Some polls suggest Cuomo could pull more votes (up to 44% in a general election), potentially overtaking Mamdani and making the race closer. If Cuomo gains traction, he could outpoll Sliwa among moderates.

Adams’ Black Voter Base: Adams’ strong support among Black voters (29% in polls) could exceed expectations, reducing Sliwa’s margin.

Progressive Mobilization: Mamdani’s viral campaign and endorsements from Bernie Sanders and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez could drive high youth turnout, countering Sliwa’s base.

Conclusion
Curtis Sliwa wins the 2025 NYC mayoral election by securing a plurality of 35% in a four-way race, capitalizing on a fractured Democratic vote, low turnout, and voter frustration with crime, taxes, and immigration. His focus on public safety, outsider status, and strong outer-borough support overcome NYC’s Democratic lean. Mamdani’s progressive platform alienates moderates, Cuomo’s independent run siphons Democratic votes, and Adams’ low approval limits his appeal beyond Black voters. Sliwa’s victory, while narrow, reflects a city seeking a “course correction” amid dissatisfaction with the establishment. Posts on X echo this hope, with supporters framing Sliwa as the candidate to “save the city.”

posts.title: Just 24 years
